Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Social and Biogenetic Factors of New Forms of Families

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research explores the relationship between the social and technological developments associated with infertility treatment and social media. First, it investigates the new kinds of relationships that emerge among children who share the same egg or sperm donor, and among the parents (and other relatives) of these "donor siblings." Second, it explores how important people think their genes are to understanding their relationships to other people. This exploration focuses on people's beliefs about how much genes shape and limit our characteristics and life outcomes. The proposed research will add to Sociology's theories of, and practical knowledge about, two related sets of issues: 1) how and why new forms of kinship are created and sustained in today's world; and 2) how individuals understand what social and biogenetic influences contribute to individual behavior and family dynamics. These issues will be explored among people who are part of various family types, people in different geographic regions, and people who represent different social, economic, and racial/ethnic groups.

The research is based on online surveys distributed to parents who have children conceived through gametes and to teens and adults who were conceived through gametes. The information from these surveys will be used to identify people who are appropriate for in-depth interviews and to provide background for what the researchers learn from those interviews. These interviews will involve parents and children from a range of family types, regions, and social positions.

This research has many broader impacts related to family and household development. It will also provide insight into new notions of considering and acting upon familial health histories. In additional to academic publishing, the investigators will enhance their own teaching about the sociology of the family and plan to design special materials about this topic that others who teach in relevant fields can adapt for their own use. Undergraduates at both Middlebury College and Wellesley College also will be involved in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Social and Biogenetic Factors of New Forms of Families

by Rosanna Hertz and Margaret K. Nelson 

We conducted our research on “Social and Biogenetic Factors of New Forms of Families” with two strategies.  First, in 2014 we launched three online surveys: one for the parents of donor-conceived offspring, one for donor-conceived offspring over the age of 13, and one for sperm and egg donors.  By the end of August, 2014 we had responses from 2,137 parents, 422 offspring and 322 donors. The co-PIs completed 7 referred articles (and a response commentary) based on these analyses. These articles were published in a broad array of professional journals including those in the disciplines of sociology, medicine and law as well as those more interdisciplinary in nature.  The co-PIs have also published two separate encyclopedia entries that draw on the knowledge they have obtained conducting this research, enabling scholars from a variety of fields to obtain the grounding necessary to begin their own projects.

Second, between July 2014 and August 2016 we conducted in-depth interviews with respondents in families relying on sperm or egg donation (212 parents in 152 different families; 154 children over the age of 10 in 11 different families; 12 donors related to the children in our study; and 7 others). The respondents live in 26 states and the District of Columbia. Through a careful analysis of the interviews with parents we learned about their individual actions: how they choose a donor and how they make the decision to contact a child’s genetic relatives.  The ever-expanding Internet and various social networking sites make this contact possible. We also learned about the individual actions of donor-conceived children: how they make sense of the donor and how they differentiate between a sibling and a donor sibling.  Finally we draw on information from five different networks of families (covering a 30-year span) in which the parents had relied on the same sperm donor. In doing so we learned how shared genetic origins provide the excitement individuals find in meeting and having contact with each other. We discuss how various new technologies have become important to maintaining connections among donor siblings and who live in different locations. We argue that in spite of an original excitement, the shared genes that are at the root of these connections are sometimes deemed entirely relevant (as when new members are identified who have the same donor) and at other times are deemed entirely insignificant (as when people decide whether they like one another).  Ultimately, we argue both parents and children discuss these relationships using a language of “connection” that emphasizes choice and social affinity rather than the inevitability of bonds created through shared genes.

The NSF grant enabled us to take five research trips to conduct these interviews.  We have shared knowledge gained through this experience in a published methods case study. The grant also enabled us to train research assistants (including some who received intensive REU training); the training they received have helped those former undergraduates gain meaningful employment upon graduation. Finally, the PIs are completing a book– tentatively titled Genetic Strangers and Contemporary Families: Creating New Kinship Possibilities – which will be accessible to both scholars and a broad population of people interested in the topic of donor conception.
